subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... The article http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/accents_spellingreform.htm Is extremely informative (it was after all I who pointed out). But some of the
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>
> I think that John Wells would advise us to follow the CMU in this
> case. Search down for the word "shutter" to find relevant discussion
> on these pages:
>
> http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/accents_spellingreform.htm
>
> http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/blog0609.htm
>
> Ted
>
>

The article

http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/accents_spellingreform.htm

Is extremely informative (it was after all I who pointed out). But
some of the specifics are inapplicable. In particular it is committed
absolutely to using the Latin letters even to the extent of
disallowing diacritics. It further more has the related goal of
minimizing the change words undergo in their new spelling with the
Latin alphabet.

qv items 5 and 6 of
http://www.spellingsociety.org/journals/j6/revisedns.php
of which group John Wells is president and to which group the first
article was addressed.

Thankfully we are free from the Latin alphabet and from this class of
restriction and the "use T for D" issue which may or may not just be
part it.

Given the use of QS letters the questions become:
- When "shutter" and "shudder" are homonyms why not use the same
letter for them? (we'd need a very good and clear reason not too:
"because they are spelled that way in TO" is not compelling)
- When "shudder" and "top" do not sound alike, why should they be
spelled with the same QS letter? Again a very compelling reason would
have to come out to put aside phonemic spelling.

There may very well be good reasons for using #3 for the D sound in
"shutter" but the only reasons I can find in the articles above is
1. it is considered by some a "bad" accent and
2. it would make the spelling of the words with Latin letters
cosmetically offensive.
I personally do not find these reasons compelling.

At any rate, we did not explicitly analyze the issue and make an
informed decision on this, we just do it because the version of the
CMU dictionary we happen to download does it. And for all we know, CMU
only does it because "...it [might have] incurred considerable
criticism [had it done otherwise]" I contend this is hardly a good
reason to add a rule to QS.
